text: hello everyone my name is shin Lee I
work as a senior technical account
manager at
AWS today I'm going to talk about the
action last access feature that AWS
identity and access management or IM
supports and how you can use it to
refine IM policies to Grant only the
permissions your IM identities require
to access and manage your workflows
action last access information is the
information where IM keeps the latest
timestamp when an IM User Group row or
policy was used to make an AWS
request first released in 2020 this
feature supported Action level last
access information for Amazon S3
service Amazon has since then
continuously invested to add support for
more
services now IM IM provides action last
access information for more than 140
services such as Amazon cloudwatch AWS
Key Management Service and elastic load
balancing IM am does authentication and
authorization authorization is
essentially about permission of who can
access what
resources we you set permissions with IM
policies the best practice is to Grant
the minimum permissions required to
perform a task this is called the
principle of least
privilege applying a least privilege
strategy helps reduce the scope of
security accidents or misuse
contributing to an improved security
poster as Eric brandwine VP and
distinguished engineer of AWS says
least privilege is maximum effort it
takes time to identify the exact minimum
permission required and to enforce
them it usually takes multiple
iterations to achieve the optimal setup
you might start with broad permissions
while you explore the minimum that are
required for your IM identities
depending on the relevant workload or
use
case as your use case matures you can
reduce the permissions that you grant to
work towards least
privilege this might take a few rounds
as shown in the picture before you
achieve the desired
State action last access information
helps you to refine the permissions
during that process for example you can
do a courtly or monthly review of the
permissions granted to IM identities
using the action lost access
information identify unused permissions
and refine to scope down the access of
your IM identities to only the services
and actions that they need to
use now let me show you where to find
the last access information on the
console on AWS console search for and
click the service I
am I will first show you the last access
information for I am
identities under the access management
menu on the left you find user groups
users rows and policies which all
support last access
information I will use rows as an
example click
rows let's take a row named payment
service developer as an
example click the row to see the the
details the permissions tab shows what
permissions we have granted this row
with what you see now currently we have
given this row a very wide range of
permissions when aiming for least
privilege but you are not sure what
exact permission the row need you might
want to start with a relaxed permission
set and gradually narrow it
down you also see here a tab named
access
advisor this is where we will see the
last access information for this
particular
row you will see two types of last
access information for IM identities
service information and action
information the information also include
the time time when the attempt was made
to access an AWS
API now click that
tab what is shown below is a list of
services this row has
accessed when it was
accessed and from which policy it the
row got the permission
from you can navigate the page numbers
to see a complete
list by clicking a specific service for
example this AWS Lambda service you can
see what Lambda actions this row has
accessed and the corresponding
time you can also see the region where
the action was
accessed I shows actions accessed in all
regions this list here includes all all
attempts that were made using the AWS
Management console the AWS API through
any of the sdks or any of the command
line
tools with all the services and actions
information here you can update the
permissions granted to this role by for
example removing permissions that this
role has not used in the last 90 days in
order to achieve a least privilege
strategy please note that if it might
take some time before recent activities
appear here in the IM
console it typically appears within 4
hours the tracking period of service
information is up to 400 Days depending
on when the corresponding Services
started tracking actions
information the tracking period for
Amazon as three actions began on April
12th 2020 the tracking period for Amazon
ec2 I IM and Lambda actions began on
April 7th
2021 the tracking period for all other
services began on May 23rd
2023 please refer to IM IM documentation
for a complete list of services for
which action lost access to information
is
available another thing you should be
aware is the service last Access Data
includes all attempts to access an AWS
API not just the successful
attempts an unexpected entry in the
service last access data does not mean
that your account has been compromised
because the request might have been
denied refer to your cloud trail logs
for detailed information whether they
were successful or denied
access if you have not given a
particular permission to the row but the
row needs it you could add that
permission as part of the refine
process similar to the
rows you can also check the action last
access information for user groups for
users and for
policies besides IM identities you can
also check last access the information
for AWS organizations entities like a
particular organization unit or an
account the last access information can
be used to help you define service
control policies in a similar way how
lost access information is used to help
Define permissions for IM
identities to view last access
information for AWS organization
entities click the organization activity
under the access reports
menu here in my example it shows an
organizations with two ous and a manage
measurement
account click an entity like the root
and ow you or an account to see the
details let's take this OU as an
example the service access report
section shows you the services that are
accessed from which account the service
was last accessed and
when the attached SCP tab here shows you
all the scps attached to this
OU you can use the last access
information to refine these scps that
are associated with this
OU as you have seen in the demo with the
support for more than 140 Services the
IM action last access information makes
it easier for you to identify and remove
any used service and Action level
permissions granted to your identities
and refine access to your workloads and
resources if you want to continuously
monitor the action lost access data to
identify inactive permissions you can
use ews config to implement an automated
procedure set up a rule that gets
triggered periodically which in turn
invokes a Lambda function then goes
through the relevant rows in your
account check the action last access the
information to identify what permissions
can be revoked based on that and then
ask AWS config to update compliance and
maintain the
state refer to the blog shown on the
screen for a reference
solution besides the action last access
information feature you can use another
feature of AWS IM called access analyzer
to further strengthen least privilege
strategy for example use it to generate
IM policies based on access activity in
your AWS cloud trail
logs please refer to the access analyzer
documentation for more
information this concludes my
introduction of the action last access
information feature of
AWS I hope this will help you in your
journey to acheve achieve least
privilege thank you for your
time
